many years upon the face of the earth;
for the greatest madness a man can
be guilty of in this life, is to let himself
die outright, without being slain
by any person whatever, or destroyed
by any other weapon than the hands
of melancholy. Hark ye, Signior!
hang sloth! get up, and let us take
the field in shepherds apparel, according
to our agreement; who knows,
but behind some bush we may find
my Lady Dulcinea disenchanted, and
a comely sight for to see? If you take
your overthrow so much to heart,
lay the blame at my door, and say
you was vanquished by my carelessness,
in girting Rozinante; besides,
your worship must have read in your
books of chivalry, that it was common
for one knight to unhorse another,
and for him who was vanquished
to-day, to be victor to-morrow.’—‘Very
true,’ said Sampson; ‘honest
Sancho seems to be very well informed
of these matters.’—‘Gentlemen,’
replied the knight, ‘let us proceed fair
and softly, without looking for this
year’s birds in last year’s nests. I
was mad; but now am in my right
senses. I was Don Quixote de La
Mancha; but now, as I have already
observed, I am Alonzo Quixano the
Good: and I hope, I shall, by my
veracity and repentance, recover that
degree of your esteem, which I formerly
enjoyed. So let Mr. Notary
proceed.’</p>

<p class="c005">‘<i>Item</i>, I bequeath my whole estate,
real and personal, to my niece Antonia
Quixano here present, after deducting
what shall be sufficient for the
payment of my debts and legacies;
and it is my will, that from the first
of the money thence arising, the
wages due to my housekeeper shall be
paid, together with twenty ducats for a
suit of mourning; and I appoint Mr.
Curate, and Mr. Batchelor Sampson
Carrasco, here present, my executors.
<i>Item</i>, It is my will, that if my niece
Antonia Quixano inclines to marriage,
she shall not wed any man until she
is fully satisfied, from previous information,
that he is an utter stranger
to books of chivalry; or, if she finds
he is addicted to this kind of reading,
and marries him nevertheless, she
shall forfeit the whole legacy, which
my executors may, in that case, dispose
of in pious uses. <i>Item</i>, I beseech
the said gentlemen, my executors,
if perchance they should become
acquainted with a certain author,
who composed and published
an history, entitled, “The Second
Part of the Atchievements of Don
Quixote de La Mancha;” that they
will, in my name, most earnestly entreat
him to forgive me for having
been the innocent cause of his writing
such a number of absurdities as
<span class="pageno" id="Page_588">588</span>that performance contains; for I quit
this life with some scruples of conscience
arising from that consideration.’
The will being thus concluded,
he was seized with a fainting-fit,
and stretched himself at full length in
the bed; so that all the company were
alarmed, and ran to his assistance.
During three days which he lived after
the will was signed and sealed,
he frequently fainted, and the whole
family was in confusion: nevertheless,
the niece eat her victuals, the housekeeper
drank to the repose of his soul,
and even Sancho cherished his little
carcase; for the prospect of succession
either dispels or moderates that affliction
which an heir ought to feel at the
death of the testator.</p>

<p class="c005">At last Don Quixote expired; after
having received all the sacraments, and
in the strongest terms, pathetically
enforced, expressed his abomination
against all books of chivalry; and the
notary observed, that in all the books
of that kind which he had perused, he
had never read of any knight-errant
who died quietly in his bed, as a good
Christian, like Don Quixote; who,
amidst the tears and lamentations of
all present, gave up the ghost, or in
other words, departed this life. The
curate was no sooner certified of his
decease, than he desired the notary to
make a testimonial, declaring, that
Alonzo Quixano the Good, commonly
called Don Quixote de La Mancha, had
taken his departure from this life, and
died of a natural death; that no other
author, different from Cid Hamet Benengeli,
should falsely pretend to raise
him from the dead, and write endless
histories of his atchievements.</p>

<p class="c005">This was the end of the sage Hidalgo
de La Mancha, whose native
place Cid Hamet would not punctually
describe, because he wished that all the
towns and villages of that province
should contend for the honour of having
given him birth, as the seven cities
of Greece contended for Homer. We
shall here omit the lamentations of the
housekeeper, niece, and squire, together
with all the epitaphs, except the following,
by Sampson Carrasco.</p>

<div class="lg-container-b c012">
  <div class="linegroup">
    <div class="group">
      <div class="line">Here lies a cavalier of fame,</div>
      <div class="line in2">Whose dauntless courage soar’d so high,</div>
      <div class="line">That death, which can the boldest tame,</div>
      <div class="line in2">He scorn’d to flatter or to fly.</div>
      <div class="line">A constant bugbear to the bad,</div>
      <div class="line in2">His might the world in arms defy’d;</div>
      <div class="line">And in his life though counted mad,</div>
      <div class="line in2">He in his perfect senses dy’d.</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

<p class="c013">The sagacious Cid Hamet addressing
himself to his pen, ‘And now, my
slender quill,’ said he, ‘whether cunningly
cut, or unskilfully formed,
it boots not much; here, from this
rack, suspended by a wire, shalt thou
enjoy repose, and live to future ages,
if no presumptuous and wicked hand
shall take thee down, in order to profane
thee in compiling idle histories.
But ere such insolent fingers can
touch thine hallowed plume, accost,
and warn them, if thou canst, in words
like these:</p>

<div class="lg-container-b c012">
  <div class="linegroup">
    <div class="group">
      <div class="line">“Caitifs, forbear!—Illustrious prince, let none</div>
      <div class="line">”Attempt th’ emprize reserv’d for me alone<a id="r213"></a><a class="c008 pginternal" href="#f213"><sup>[213]</sup></a>.”</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

<p class="c013">‘For me alone was Don Quixote born,
and I produced for him; he to act,
and I to record: in a word, we were
destined for each other, maugre and
in despight of that fictitious Tordesilian
author, who has presumed, or
may presume, to write with his coarse,
aukward ostrich quill, the atchievements
of my valiant knight; a burden
too heavy for his weak shoulders,
and an undertaking too great for his
frozen genius. Advise him, therefore,
if ever thou shouldst chance to
be in his company, to let the wearied
and mouldering bones of Don Quixote
rest in the grave, without seeking
to carry him into Old Castile<a id="r214"></a><a class="c008 pginternal" href="#f214"><sup>[214]</sup></a>, in
opposition to all the prerogatives of
death; or to drag him from his tomb,
where he really and truly lies extended
at full length, and utterly
incapable of making a third
sally: for all the exploits performed
by the whole tribe of knights-errant
are sufficiently ridiculed by the two
expeditions he has already made, so
much to the satisfaction and entertainment,
<span class="pageno" id="Page_589">589</span>not only of Spain, but also
of every foreign nation to which the
fame of his adventures hath been
conveyed. In so doing, thou wilt
conform to thy Christian profession of
doing good to those who would do
thee harm; and I shall rest satisfied
and perfectly well pleased, in seeing
myself the first author who fully enjoyed
the fruit of his writings in the
success of his design: for mine was
no other than to inspire mankind with
an abhorrence of the false and improbable
stories recounted in books
of chivalry; which are already shaken
by the adventures of my true and
genuine Don Quixote, and in a little
time will certainly sink into oblivion.
Farewel.’</p>
<p class="c004">FINIS.</p>

that those who are once delivered seldom think of performing the promises they have
made in captivity: as a confirmation of the truth of what he alledged, he briefly recounted
a case which had lately happened to some Christian gentlemen, attended with the strangest
circumstances ever known, even in those parts, where the most uncommon and surprizing

<div class="footnote" id="f14">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r14" class="pginternal">14</a>.  </span>Alluding to the loss of his hand in the battle of Lepanto.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f15">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r15" class="pginternal">15</a>.  </span>Mutton in Spain is counted greatly preferable to beef.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f16">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r16" class="pginternal">16</a>.  </span><i>Salpicon</i>, which is the word in the original, is no other than cold beef sliced, and
eaten with oil, vinegar, and pepper.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f17">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r17" class="pginternal">17</a>.  </span>Gripes and grumblings, in Spanish <span lang="es"><i>duelos y quebrantos</i></span>; the true meaning of which
the former translators have been at great pains to investigate, as the importance of the
subject (no doubt) required. But their labours have, unhappily, ended in nothing else
but conjectures, which, for the entertainment and instruction of our readers, we beg leave
to repeat. One interprets the phrase into collops and eggs; ‘Being,’ saith he, ‘a very
sorry dish.’ In this decision, however, he is contradicted by another commentator,
who affirms, ‘It is a mess too good to mortify withal:’ neither can this virtuoso agree
with a late editor, who translates the passage in question into an amlet; but takes occasion
to fall out with Boyer for his description of that dish, which he most sagaciously understands
to be a ‘bacon froize,’ or ‘rather fryze, from its being fried, from frit in French;’
and concludes with this judicious query, ‘After all these learned disquisitions, who knows
but the author means a dish of nichils?’ If this was his meaning, indeed, surely we
may venture to conclude, that fasting was very expensive in La Mancha; for the author
mentions the <span lang="es"><i>duelos y quebrantos</i></span> among those articles that confirmed three-fourths of the
knight’s income.</p>

<p class="c005">Having considered this momentous affair with all the deliberation it deserves, we in our
turn present the reader with cucumbers, greens, or pease-porridge, as the fruit of our industrious
researches; being thereunto determined by the literal signification of the text,
which is not ‘grumblings and groanings,’ as the last-mentioned ingenious annotator seems
to think, but rather pains and breakings; and evidently points at such eatables as generate
and expel wind; qualities (as every body knows) eminently inherent in those vegetables we
have mentioned as our hero’s Saturday’s repast.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f18">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r18" class="pginternal">18</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Podadera</i></span>, literally signifies a pruning-hook.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f19">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r19" class="pginternal">19</a>.  </span>In the original, a lover of hunting.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f20">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r20" class="pginternal">20</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Quixadas</i></span>, signifies jaws, of which our knight had an extraordinary provision.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f21">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r21" class="pginternal">21</a>.  </span>Siguenza, a town situated on the banks of the Henares, in New Castile, in which
there is a small university.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f22">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r22" class="pginternal">22</a>.  </span>Hidalgo has much the same application in Spain as squire in England; though it
literally signifies the son of something, in contradistinction to those who are the sons of
nothing.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f23">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r23" class="pginternal">23</a>.  </span>Orlando, the supposed nephew of Charlemagne, and poetical hero of Boiardo and
Ariosto, is said to have been invulnerable in all parts of his body, except the soles of his
feet, which he therefore took care to secure with double plates of armour.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f24">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r24" class="pginternal">24</a>.  </span>Galalon is said to have betrayed Charlemagne’s army at Roncevalles, where it was
roughly handled by the Moors, in his retreat from Spain.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f25">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r25" class="pginternal">25</a>.  </span>This is a joke upon the knight’s steed, which was so meagre, that his bones stuck
out like the corners of a Spanish rial, a coin of very irregular shape, not unlike the figure in
geometry called a trapezium.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f26">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r26" class="pginternal">26</a>.  </span>Rozinante, implies that which was formerly an ordinary horse, though the <i>ante</i>
seems to have been intended by the knight as a badge of distinction, by which he was ranked
before all other horses.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f27">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r27" class="pginternal">27</a>.  </span>According to the ancient rules of chivalry, no man was entitled to the rank and
degree of knighthood, until he had been in actual battle, and taken a prisoner with his
own hand.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f28">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r28" class="pginternal">28</a>.  </span>It was common for one knight to dub another. Francis <abbr title="the first">I.</abbr> King of France, was
knighted, at his own desire, by the Chevalier Bayard, who was looked upon as the flower
of chivalry.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f29">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r29" class="pginternal">29</a>.  </span>He might have imitated the young knight described in Perce Forest, who having
been dubbed by King Alexander, rode into a wood, and attacked the trees with such
fury and address, that the king and his whole court were convinced of his prowess and
dexterity.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f30">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r30" class="pginternal">30</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Sano de Castella</i></span>, signifies a crafty knave.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f31">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r31" class="pginternal">31</a>.  </span>This circumstance of the ladies disarming the knight, is exactly conformable to the
practice of chivalry; though his refusing to lay aside his helmet is no great argument of
his courtesy or attachment to the laws and customs of his profession; for, among knights,
it was looked upon as an indispensible mark of respect, to appear without the helmet in
church, and in presence of ladies, or respectable personages; and, indeed, in those iron
times, this was considered as a necessary mark and proof of peaceable intention: hence we
derive the custom of uncovering the head in salutation.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f32">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r32" class="pginternal">32</a>.  </span>In the original, or kid to he-goat.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f33">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r33" class="pginternal">33</a>.  </span>This request was a little premature, inasmuch as the practice of chivalry did not
authorize the suppliant to ask a boon of his godfather, until he was dubbed, and then he
had a right to demand it.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f34">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r34" class="pginternal">34</a>.  </span>Literally, the colt of Cordova, because the water gushes out of a fountain resembling
an horse’s mouth. These are places of resort frequented by thieves and sharpers.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f35">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r35" class="pginternal">35</a>.  </span>Here the landlord was more selfish than observant of the customs of chivalry; for
knights were actually exempted from all expence whatever; except when damages were
awarded against them in a court of justice; and in that case they paid for their rank.
This they looked upon as a mark of their pre-eminence; in consequence of which, at
the siege of Dun le Roy, in the year 1411, each knight was ordered to carry eight fascines,
while the squire was quit for half the number.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f36">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r36" class="pginternal">36</a>.  </span>This custom of watching armour in church or chapel, was a religious duty imposed
upon knights, who used to consume the whole night in prayer to some saint, whom they
chose as their patron; and this exercise of devotion was performed on the night preceding
the said saint’s day. The same ceremony was observed by those who were sentenced
to the combat-proof.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f37">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r37" class="pginternal">37</a>.  </span>The slap on the shoulders, and the box on the ear being bestowed, the godfather pronounced,
‘In the name of God, <abbr title="Saint">St.</abbr> Michael, and <abbr title="Saint">St.</abbr> George, I dub thee knight: be
worthy, bold, and loyal.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f38">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r38" class="pginternal">38</a>.  </span>The author seems to have committed a small oversight in this paragraph; for the
knight had not been gone above two days and one night, which he spent in watching his
armour.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f39">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r39" class="pginternal">39</a>.  </span>The name of a good-natured inchantress in Amadis de Gaul. During the age of
knight-errantry, it was usual for ladies to study the art of surgery, in order to dress the
wounds of those knights who were their servants. One of the heroines of Perce Forest
says to Norgal, ‘Fair nephew, methinks your arm is not at ease.’—‘In faith, dear lady,’
answered Norgal, ‘you are in the right; and I beseech you to take it under your care.’
Then she called her daughter Helen, who entertained her cousin with good cheer, and afterwards
reduced his arm which was dislocated.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f40">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r40" class="pginternal">40</a>.  </span>In the original, <i>Quirielyson</i>, from the two Greek words κύριε ἐλέησον, signifying,
Lord have mercy.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f41">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r41" class="pginternal">41</a>.  </span>How comes Juana to be so suddenly metamorphosed into Mary?</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f42">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r42" class="pginternal">42</a>.  </span>Here Don Quixote seems to have been too scrupulous: for though no squire was permitted
to engage with a knight on horseback, yet they were allowed, and even enjoined,
to assist their masters when they were unhorsed or in danger, by mounting them on fresh
steeds, supplying them with arms, and warding off the blows that were aimed at them;
Davy Gam, at the battle of Agincourt, lost his life in defending Henry <abbr title="the fifth">V.</abbr> of England,
and Saint Severin met with the same fate in warding off the blows that were aimed at
Francis <abbr title="the first">I.</abbr> of France, in the battle of Pavia.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f43">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r43" class="pginternal">43</a>.  </span>The literal meaning of the Spanish is, ‘Thou shalt soon see who is to carry the cat to
the water:’ or rather, in the corrupted Biscayan phrase, ‘The water how soon thou wilt
see, that thou carriest to the cat.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f44">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r44" class="pginternal">44</a>.  </span>The behaviour of Don Quixote was exactly conformable to the rules of chivalry;
which, though they hindered a knight from fighting in armour with a squire, did not prevent
him from giving satisfaction to an inferior, at sword and target; and every squire who
was aggrieved had a right to demand it.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f45">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r45" class="pginternal">45</a>.  </span>Panza, in Castilian, signifies Paunch; and Zancas, Spindle-shanks.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f46">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r46" class="pginternal">46</a>.  </span>Santa Hermandad was a brotherhood or society instituted in Spain in times of confusion,
to suppress robbery, and render travelling safe.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f47">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r47" class="pginternal">47</a>.  </span>These ridiculous oaths or vows are not confined to romances. Philip, the good
Duke of Burgundy, at a publick banquet, vowed to God, the holy virgin, the peacock,
and the ladies, that he would declare war against the infidels; and a great number of
persons who were present, listed themselves under the same vow, and incurred voluntary
penance until it should be accomplished. Some swore they would never lie upon a bed,
others renounced the use of a table-cloth, a third set obliged themselves to fast one particular
day in the week, a fourth went without one particular piece of armour, a fifth
wore his armour night and day, and many confined themselves to shirts of sackcloth
and hair.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f48">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r48" class="pginternal">48</a>.  </span>Geoffroi de Rançon, having been injured by the Count de La Marche, swore by the
saints that he would wear his buskin like a woman, and never suffer himself to be shaved
in the manner of chivalry, until he should be revenged. This oath he scrupulously observed,
until he saw his adversary, with his wife and children, kneeling in distress before
the king, and imploring his forgiveness; then he called for a stool, adjusted his buskin,
and was shaved in presence of his majesty and the court.</p>

<p class="c005">The knight’s forehead was commonly shaved, that in case he should lose his helmet
in combat, his antagonist should have no hold by which he might be pulled off his
horse.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f49">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r49" class="pginternal">49</a>.  </span>We read in Perce Forest, that there were flat stones placed at certain distances in
uninhabited parts of the country, for the use of knights-errant; who, having killed a
roe-buck, pressed the blood out of it upon one of these tables by the help of another
smooth stone, and then eat it with some salt and spices, which they carried along with
them for that purpose. This diet is called in the French romances, <span lang="fr"><i>Chevraux de presse,
nourreture des heraux</i></span>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f50">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r50" class="pginternal">50</a>.  </span>Volatile, in the original, signifies any things that fly; and therefore Sancho may
be supposed to mean, he would provide himself with game or poultry; but the blunder
which we have made him commit seems to be more in character.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f51">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r51" class="pginternal">51</a>.  </span>A sort of small fiddle of one piece, with three strings, used by shepherds.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f52">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r52" class="pginternal">52</a>.  </span>The reader will perceive that I have endeavoured to adapt the versification to the
plainness and rusticity of the sentiment, which are preserved through the whole of this
ballad; though all the other translators seem to have been bent upon setting the poetry at
variance with the pastoral simplicity of the thoughts. For example, who would ever
dream of a goatherd’s addressing his mistress in these terms?</p>

<div class="lg-container-b c012">
  <div class="linegroup">
    <div class="group">
      <div class="line">‘With rapture on each charm I dwell,</div>
      <div class="line in2">‘And daily spread thy beauty’s fame;</div>
      <div class="line">‘And still my tongue thy praise shall tell,</div>
      <div class="line in2">‘Though envy swell, or malice blame.’</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

<p class="c013">The original sentiments which this courtly stanza is designed to translate, are literally
these:</p>

<p class="c005">‘I do not mention the praises I have spoke of your beauty, which, though true in
fact, are the occasion of my being hated by some other women.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f53">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r53" class="pginternal">53</a>.  </span>In the original Spanish, the goatherd, instead of saying as old as Sarah, says, as old
as Sarna, which in that language signifies the itch; but as it is impossible to preserve
these mistakes in the translation, I have substituted another in its room, which I apprehend
is equally natural and expressive.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f54">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r54" class="pginternal">54</a>.  </span>When a knight challenged the whole world, he wore an emprize, consisting of a
gold chain, or some other badge of love and chivalry; and sometimes this emprize was
fixed in a publick place, to attract the attention of strangers. When any person accepted
the challenge for a trial of chivalry, called the combat of courtesy, he touched this emprize;
but, if he tore it away, it was considered as a resolution to fight the owner to extremity
or outrance. The combat of courtesy is still practised by our prize-fighters and
boxers, who shake hands before the engagement, in token of love.</p>

<p class="c005">But no defiance of this kind could be either published or accepted without the permission
of the prince at whose court the combatants chanced to be. Accordingly, we are
told by Oliver de La Marche, that the lord of Ternant having published a defiance at
the court of Burgundy, in the year 1445, Galiot asked the duke’s permission to touch
the challenger’s emprize; which being granted, he advanced and touched it, saying to
the bearer, while he bowed very low, ‘Noble knight, I touch your emprize; and, with
God’s permission, will do my utmost to fulfil your desire, either on horseback or on
foot.’ The lord of Ternant humbly thanked him for his condescension, said he was
extremely welcome, and promised to send him that same day a cartel, mentioning the
arms they should use.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f55">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r55" class="pginternal">55</a>.  </span>Cachopines is the name given to the Europeans by the Indians of Mexico.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f56">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r56" class="pginternal">56</a>.  </span>Tizona, which is the word in the original, is a romantick name given to the sword
that belonged to Roderick Dias de Bivar, the famous Spanish general against the Moors.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f57">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r57" class="pginternal">57</a>.  </span>Literally, what is left in the bottom of his inkhorn.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f58">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r58" class="pginternal">58</a>.  </span>Don Quixote seems in this place to have forgot one adventure of his great pattern,
Orlando, who, while he accompanied Angelica in her flight from Albracca, happened
to intrude upon the king of the Lestrigons as he sat at dinner in a valley; and being in
great want of victuals, accosted his most savage majesty in these words, recorded by Boyardo,
or rather Berni, in his poem intitled Orlando Innamorato.</p>

<div class="lg-container-b c012">
  <div class="linegroup">
    <div class="group">
      <div class="line"><i>Poichè fortuna a quest’ora ne mena</i></div>
      <div class="line"><i>Da voi, vi prego, che non vi despiaccia,</i></div>
      <div class="line"><i>O pe nostri danari o in cortesia,</i></div>
      <div class="line"><i>Che noi cenium con voi di compagnia.</i></div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

<p class="c013">Thus humbly requesting, that he would either for love or money give them a bone to
pick.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f59">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r59" class="pginternal">59</a>.  </span>In the original, from Ceca to Mecca; a phrase derived from the customs of the
Moors, who used to go in pilgrimage to these two places. Ceca was in the city of Cordova.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f60">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r60" class="pginternal">60</a>.  </span>Zebra is a beautiful creature, native of Arabia, vulgarly called the wild ass.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f61">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r61" class="pginternal">61</a>.  </span>I have endeavoured to preserve an alliteration in tooth and treasure, after the example
of Cervantes, who seems to have intended it, in the words <span lang="es"><i>diente</i></span> and <span lang="es"><i>diamante</i></span>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f62">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r62" class="pginternal">62</a>.  </span>Knights engaged themselves, by oath, to protect the widow and the orphan, to redress
all injuries; and, in a special manner, to defend the characters of ladies by force
of arms.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f63">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r63" class="pginternal">63</a>.  </span>In Castilian, <span lang="es"><i>bocina</i></span> signifies a cornet, or hunting-horn, to which the Spaniards
suppose the constellation of Ursa Minor bears some resemblance.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f64">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r64" class="pginternal">64</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Oregano</i></span>, in the original, signifies sweet marjoram; as if Sancho had wished his
master might find a nosegay, rather than a bloody nose.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f65">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r65" class="pginternal">65</a>.  </span>The Spaniards of old paid a tribute of five hundred sueldos, or pieces of coin, to the
Moors, until they were delivered from this imposition by the gallantry of the gentlemen
or people of rank, from which exploit a Castilian of family used to express the nobility
and worth of his extraction, by saying he was of the revenge of the Sueldos.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f66">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r66" class="pginternal">66</a>.  </span>Literally, ‘Never beg when you can take.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f67">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r67" class="pginternal">67</a>.  </span>In the original, ‘A snatch from behind a bush is better than the prayer of good
men.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f68">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r68" class="pginternal">68</a>.  </span>This seems to have been intended as a stroke of satire against those princes who sell
nobility to the highest bidder, without any regard to the merit of the purchaser.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f69">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r69" class="pginternal">69</a>.  </span>A crime that is punished by the pillory in England, is in Spain expiated by the
convict’s being mounted upon an ass, in a particular dress, and led through the streets by
a crier, who proclaims the transgression.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f70">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r70" class="pginternal">70</a>.  </span>This is a good hint for a reforming legislature.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f71">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r71" class="pginternal">71</a>.  </span>It was the custom of knights to wear a coat of arms made of some rich stuff figured
in a particular manner. The Duke of Brabant being called in a hurry to the battle of
Agincourt, took a trumpeter’s banner, and making a hole through the middle, put it
over his head, and wore it as his coat of arms.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f72">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r72" class="pginternal">72</a>.  </span>This is an oversight of the author, who seems to have forgot that Sancho lost his
wallet at the inn, and was robbed by the galley-slaves of the great coat or cloak, in
which he carried the remains of that provision he had taken from those who attended the
dead body towards Segovia.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f73">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r73" class="pginternal">73</a>.  </span>A chain of dusky mountains that divide Castile from Andalusia.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f74">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r74" class="pginternal">74</a>.  </span>Here Cervantes hath been caught napping by the criticks; who observe, that Sancho

</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f75">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r75" class="pginternal">75</a>.  </span>As it is impossible to preserve the original blunders of Sancho, who mistakes Fili or
Phillis, for Hilo, that signifies a thread, we are obliged to substitute another, by changing
Phillis into Chloe, which Sancho, in English, might have as naturally mistaken for
a clue; and by this expedient the sense of the passage is not hurt, and but very little altered.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f76">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r76" class="pginternal">76</a>.  </span>Methinks it is inconsistent with the character of the knight, to allow Sancho to tell

</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f77">

<div class="footnote" id="f81">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r81" class="pginternal">81</a>.  </span>Bamba, or Wamba, king of the Visigoths in Spain, mounted the throne in the year

</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f84">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r84" class="pginternal">84</a>.  </span>The original <span lang="es"><i>pues presente pocas vezes lo bazía</i></span>, signifies, ‘Since while I was present
she did it very seldom.’ This at first sight appears a solecism, and the petulant critick
will exclaim, ‘What occasion had she to write to her lover who was present, unless she
had lost the faculty of speech!’ But the seeming absurdity will vanish, when we reflect
that by <i>present</i>, he means, in the same city with his mistress; to whom, however, according
to the custom of Spain, he had little or no access but by a literary correspondence.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f85">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r85" class="pginternal">85</a>.  </span>As if he had said Ape-land, <span lang="es"><i>mico</i></span> signifying an ape.</p>

<div class="footnote" id="f86">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r86" class="pginternal">86</a>.  </span>When a knight had once granted a boon in this manner, it was impossible for him to
retract, let the request be never so extravagant. We are told by Joinville, that the queen
of <abbr title="Saint">St.</abbr> Lewis, being big with child, and in the utmost terror of falling alive into the hands
of the infidels at Damietta in Egypt, fell upon her knees before an old knight turned
of fourscore, and conjured him to grant her boon: the old man having promised to comply,
on the faith of his knighthood, she told him the favour she so pressingly solicited,
was, that he would cut off her head before she should fall into the hands of the enemy,
provided the Saracens should become masters of the town. The senior answered without
hesitation, that she might depend upon his sword; and owned he had taken that resolution
even before she signified her request.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f87">

<div class="footnote" id="f100">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r100" class="pginternal">100</a>.  </span>The literal translation is, ‘For, from the skirts—for I would not mention the
‘sleeves.’ The Spaniards, instead of the English phrase, ‘By Hook or by Crook,’ use this
of ‘From the sleeves, or the skirts;’ derived from the practice of taylors, who are supposed
to cabbage from those parts of the habit in which there is the greatest quantity
of cloth; but the knight’s exception of sleeves, on this occasion, seems to have proceeded
from a supposition that poor scholars are generally provided for in the church, and
consequently wear cassocks, which descend to the heels.</p>

<div class="footnote" id="f129">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r129" class="pginternal">129</a>.  </span>Ridiculous as this scheme may seem to be, such an expedient has actually succeeded
in practice. During the captivity of John King of France, his dominions were ravaged
by above one hundred thousand peasants, who, under the name of Jacquieers, assembled
in arms to exterminate the noblesse; and among other horrid outrages, murdered
every gentleman that fell in their way. The Duchess of Normandy and Orleans, together
with three hundred ladies of rank, retired for protection to Meaux, where they
were surrounded, and would have actually perished by the swords of these banditti, had
they not been rescued by the Count de Foix, and the captal of Buch; who, hearing of
their distress, hastened to their relief with no more than sixty knights; and, without
hesitation, attacked that furious multitude with such bravery and vigour, that they were
soon routed and dispersed.</p>

</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f140">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r140" class="pginternal">140</a>.  </span>This is the cry uttered by the Spaniards when they charge in battle.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f141">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r141" class="pginternal">141</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Baylar el agua delante</i></span>, is a phrase applicable to those who do their duty with alacrity,
taken from the practice of watering the courts in Spain, an office which the maids
perform with a motion that resembles dancing.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f142">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r142" class="pginternal">142</a>.  </span>Alonzo de Ercilla, author of the Auraucana; Juan Rufo de Cordova, author of the
Austriada; Christopher Verves de Valentia, author of the Monserratte; and as for the
half, Cervantes in all probability meant himself.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f143">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r143" class="pginternal">143</a>.  </span>Sancho’s wife has already been mentioned under the names of Juana and Mary, and
now she is called Teresa.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f144">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r144" class="pginternal">144</a>.  </span>Almohada signifies a cushion.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f145">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r145" class="pginternal">145</a>.  </span>Alluding to the bough that is adorned and carried in procession on Palm Sunday.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f146">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r146" class="pginternal">146</a>.  </span>A dress put upon convicted hereticks.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f147">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r147" class="pginternal">147</a>.  </span>The original, <span lang="es"><i>ventura</i></span>, signifies good luck as well as adventures.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f148">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r148" class="pginternal">148</a>.  </span>I have substituted this play upon the word proportion, in lieu of Sancho’s blundering
on <span lang="es"><i>rata</i></span>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f149">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r149" class="pginternal">149</a>.  </span>Like our Chevy Chase.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f150">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r150" class="pginternal">150</a>.  </span>As the original quotation is a fragment that will not complete the sense, I have
taken the liberty to make the allusion altogether English.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f151">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r151" class="pginternal">151</a>.  </span>Literally, ‘a squire of wool and water,’ an allusion to a custom among the Spaniards,
who sometimes have domesticks to attend them to mass, and sprinkle them with
holy water: these are generally shabby fellows, who have very poor appointments.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f152">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r152" class="pginternal">152</a>.  </span>A brass statue on a steeple at Seville, serving for a weather-cock.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f153">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r153" class="pginternal">153</a>.  </span>These are stone statues of bulls, erected by the Romans at Guisando, a town in
Castile; all the inscriptions are effaced, except the name of <abbr class="spell">A.</abbr> Quintus Cæcilius,
Consul <abbr class="spell">II</abbr>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f154">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r154" class="pginternal">154</a>.  </span>Poor people that live about Zamora.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f155">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r155" class="pginternal">155</a>.  </span>Zocodover, a square in Toledo, like Smithfield, where cattle are sold.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f156">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r156" class="pginternal">156</a>.  </span>In the original there is a play upon the words <span lang="es">Descarnado</span>, <span lang="es">Cordero</span>, and <span lang="es">Carnero</span>,
which I have endeavoured to imitate, by substituting goose in the room of mutton, which
is the literal meaning of the text.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f157">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r157" class="pginternal">157</a>.  </span>The patina was a small consecrated plate which the Spanish women, especially those
of an inferior rank, wore upon their breasts.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f158">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r158" class="pginternal">158</a>.  </span>Fouckar was a very rich merchant of Augsburg, and a great favourite of Charles
<abbr title="the fifth">V.</abbr> who owed him a very considerable sum. It is reported of him, that when the emperor
lodged at his house, in his return from Tunis, the fire in his chamber was of cinnamon,
and his landlord lighted it with his imperial majesty’s own obligation, thereby
cancelling an immense debt. The wealth of these traders, for there were two brothers,
became proverbial, and it was usual to say of any very opulent person, ‘He is as rich as
a Fouckar.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f159">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r159" class="pginternal">159</a>.  </span>This was the great patron of the Portuguese discoveries along the coast of Africa to
the Cape of Good Hope.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f160">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r160" class="pginternal">160</a>.  </span>A knavish trick.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f161">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r161" class="pginternal">161</a>.  </span>In the original there is a miserable pun upon the words Mono and Mona, the first
of which signifies an ape, and the other drunkenness.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f162">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r162" class="pginternal">162</a>.  </span>Literally, ‘When choler quits the mother, the tongue has then no father.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f163">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r163" class="pginternal">163</a>.  </span>I have ventured to deviate a little from the precise meaning of the original, which
the reader will own to be very insipid when he reads the literal translation: ‘For it would
be good, if the inhabitants of the town of Reloxa,’ (signifying a watch, or clock)
‘should, at every turn, slay those that call them so.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f164">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r164" class="pginternal">164</a>.  </span>As it is altogether impossible, in a translation, literally to preserve the low humour
arising from blunders upon words or sounds, I have been obliged to substitute an equivalent
jingle, in the room of <span lang="es"><i>puto</i></span>, <span lang="es"><i>gafo</i></span> and <span lang="es"><i>meon</i></span>, which are Spanish words, signifying, a
a <i>whore</i>, a <i>catamite</i>, and a <i>piss-a-bed</i>: so that Sancho, deceived by the affinity of these
sounds to <i>computo</i>, <i>cosmographa</i>, and <i>Ptolemeo</i>, thought he had reason to say his master
had produced a fair set of evidences.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f165">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r165" class="pginternal">165</a>.  </span>In allusion to the speech that Virgil puts in the mouth of Panthus Othryades, who
says to Æneas,</p>

<div class="lg-container-b c012">
  <div class="linegroup">
    <div class="group">
      <div class="line">——<span lang="la"><i>fuit Ilium, et ingens</i></span></div>
      <div class="line"><span lang="la"><i>Gloria Teucrorum!</i></span></div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f166">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r166" class="pginternal">166</a>.  </span>Sayago is a district in the kingdom of Leon, the inhabitants of which were extremely
poor, and very meanly cloathed.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f167">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r167" class="pginternal">167</a>.  </span>In Spain and Italy there is, upon every Holy Thursday, a procession of disciplinants, or
people who do penance in sackcloth, carrying a flambeau in one hand, and in the other a
scourge, with which they belabour their own shoulders, in such a manner, that the very
street is sometimes coloured with their blood: some of these disciplinants, however, are
mere hypocrites, who under their sackcloth wear women’s stay’s, buff jackets, and even
plates of tin; so that they are often detected from the sound of the stroke: and at Rome
nothing is more common than to hear the people who accompany these devotees, call out,
according to the report of the application, ‘<span lang="it"><i>Guipponi di Buffalo!—Busti di Donna!</i></span> and
<span lang="it"><i>Corrazini di Latta!</i></span>’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f168">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r168" class="pginternal">168</a>.  </span><span lang="es">‘<i>Su alma en su palma.</i>’</span> The original expression literally signifies, ‘His soul is in
his hand,’ <abbr class="spell">i. e.</abbr> ‘He is at his own discretion.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f169">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r169" class="pginternal">169</a>.  </span>In Spain the people always retire after dinner, and sleep till six o’clock, whence
the afternoon’s nap is called <span lang="es"><i>siesta</i></span>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f170">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r170" class="pginternal">170</a>.  </span>This is an expression proverbially applied to any story that is vague, inconsistent, or of
dubious authority; for the hills of Ubeda make an extensive chain, the different parts of
which are differently denominated, from the different countries or districts through which it
extends; so that the whole is not easily ascertained.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f171">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r171" class="pginternal">171</a>.  </span>In the original, ‘And thoroughly understand “<i>Tus, tus</i>”’; which is an expression in
Spain, to wheedle a cur.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f172">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r172" class="pginternal">172</a>.  </span>A young Florentine, of great genius, who died in the seventeenth year of his age, and
was lamented by all the poets of his time.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f173">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r173" class="pginternal">173</a>.  </span>Literally, ‘And you shall see it will be worth a loaf that will serve a hundred.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f174">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r174" class="pginternal">174</a>.  </span><span lang="la"><i>Disciplinante de lux</i></span>, is a cant phrase, applied to those who are exposed to publick
shame.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f175">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r175" class="pginternal">175</a>.  </span>Literally, <span lang="es"><i>cacique</i></span>, which was the appellation given to Indian princes.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f176">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r176" class="pginternal">176</a>.  </span>The other translators have interpreted <span lang="es"><i>mosqueo</i></span> into a fly-flap, which is undoubtedly
one of his meanings; but as it likewise signifies flagellation at the cart’s tail, I
have taken it in this last acceptation, which, I think, heightens the humour of the
passage.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f177">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r177" class="pginternal">177</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Faldis</i></span>, in Spain, signifies skirts.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f178">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r178" class="pginternal">178</a>.  </span>A kind of pea that grows at Martos, a town in the province of Andalusia.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f179">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r179" class="pginternal">179</a>.  </span>This blunder is much more natural in the Spanish <span lang="es"><i>criado</i></span> for <span lang="es"><i>criada</i></span>; but, as in the
English language, the gender is not distinguished by the termination, I have been obliged
to substitute the words varlet and handmaid. Varlets were the servants of yeomen, though
formerly squires were known by that appellation.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f180">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r180" class="pginternal">180</a>.  </span>Or, in English, ‘Wooden Peg the Winged.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f181">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r181" class="pginternal">181</a>.  </span>Equivalent to Abington law; in consequence of which, a criminal is first executed,
and then tried. Peralvillo is a village near Ciuidad Real, in Castile, where the officers of
the holy brotherhood execute robbers taken <i>in flagrante</i>, who require no trial. Hence the
phrase, <span lang="es">‘<i>La justicia de Peralvillo, que aborcado el hombre, le baze la Pesquisa</i>.’</span> <abbr class="spell">i. e.</abbr>
‘Peralvillo law, which begins the process after the man is hanged.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f182">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r182" class="pginternal">182</a>.  </span>In Spain, the Pleiades are vulgarly called <span lang="es"><i>cabrillas</i></span>, <abbr class="spell">i. e.</abbr> nanny-goats.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f183">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r183" class="pginternal">183</a>.  </span>There is a kind of pleasantry in this question of the duke, which cannot be translated;
for the Spanish word, <span lang="es"><i>cabron</i></span>, signifies a cuckold, as well as an he-goat.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f184">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r184" class="pginternal">184</a>.  </span>The phrase, <span lang="es"><i>No quiero de tu capilla</i></span>, alludes to the practice of friars, who, when
charity is offered, hold out their hoods to receive it, while they pronounce a refusal with
their tongues.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f185">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r185" class="pginternal">185</a>.  </span>Instead of <i>saintly</i>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f186">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r186" class="pginternal">186</a>.  </span>Cervantes has been frequently caught napping, and here in particular: How could
this be any proof of the antiquity of ruffs, when the adventure happened after the first
part of Don Quixote was published? But, perhaps, this is no other than an ironical
animadversion upon the trifling discoveries of antiquarians.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f187">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r187" class="pginternal">187</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Barato</i></span>, signifies cheap.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f188">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r188" class="pginternal">188</a>.  </span>The Spanish name is Pedro Rezio de Aguero; which, together with Tirte Afuera,
the place of his nativity, I have translated into English, that the humour may be better
understood.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f189">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r189" class="pginternal">189</a>.  </span>The original <span lang="es"><i>Ponga en pretina</i></span>, signifies, I will put in my girdle.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f190">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r190" class="pginternal">190</a>.  </span>She is in the original called Perlerina, which I have changed into Paralina, in order
to preserve the subsequent play on the words.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f191">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r191" class="pginternal">191</a>.  </span><span lang="es"><i>Podrida</i></span>, signifies rotten or mortified; hence the <span lang="es"><i>olla podrida</i></span> is in French stiled
<span lang="fr"><i>pot-pourri</i></span>.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f192">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r192" class="pginternal">192</a>.  </span>Literally, The devil’s in Cantiliana, which is a town of Andalusia, near Seville.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f193">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r193" class="pginternal">193</a>.  </span>Literally, the Aranjuez of the fountains. <span lang="es"><i>Fuentes</i></span> signifies, either fountains or
issues; and <span lang="es"><i>Aranjeuz</i></span> is the name of a delightful palace, about seven leagues from Madrid,
famous for gardens and fountains.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f194">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r194" class="pginternal">194</a>.  </span>This was a Moorish princess, for whom her father built a stately palace near the
Tagus, the ruins of which remain to this day.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f195">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r195" class="pginternal">195</a>.  </span>A critick inclined to enumerate the inadvertencies of Cervantes, might observe that
Sancho pulled a piece of bread out of his wallet and gave it to Dapple, after he had
given the contents of the said wallet to the pilgrims; that he tells the duke and duchess
he had governed ten days, whereas he had continued but seven days in office; and, lastly,
that Tosilos contemplated the beauties of the damsel, though we are previously told that
she was veiled down to the bosom.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f196">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r196" class="pginternal">196</a>.  </span>In the romance of Gerard de Nevers we read, that a certain young lady, perceiving
the eagerness with which that knight undertook her defence, pulled the glove from her
left-hand, and presented it to him, saying, ‘Sir Knight, my body, life, lands, and honour,
I commit to the protection of God and you, to whom I pray he may grant grace
to obtain the victory, and deliver us from the danger in which we are now involved.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f197">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r197" class="pginternal">197</a>.  </span>Moor-killer.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f198">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r198" class="pginternal">198</a>.  </span>The original word is Mendoza, the name of a great family in Spain, one of whom
was remarkably superstitious.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f199">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r199" class="pginternal">199</a>.  </span>The Moors are said to be descended from Hagar.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f200">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r200" class="pginternal">200</a>.  </span>Sancho must have been very simple indeed, to be satisfied with this explanation, which
does not even hint at the main point of his question; namely, Why do the Spanish soldiers,
when they charge their enemy, cry, ‘Close, Spain?’ A phrase of encouragement, by
which the soldiers exhort one another to do their duty, and close with the foe.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f201">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r201" class="pginternal">201</a>.  </span>Why might not this innkeeper have had eggs in his house, as he had sent no less than
fifty pullets to market the very day before?</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f202">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r202" class="pginternal">202</a>.  </span>I am apt to believe that this remark was intended as an ironical sarcasm on the trivial
observations of hypercriticks: for we cannot suppose Cervantes did not know, by this time,
that he himself had more than once, in the first part of this history, actually called Sancho’s
wife by the name of Mary Gutierrez; an oversight which I have taken notice of in the
proper place.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f203">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r203" class="pginternal">203</a>.  </span>The proverb in the original, alludes to a kind of tabor: as if one should say, ‘He
alone should attempt to play, who knows how to beat the tabor.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f204">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r204" class="pginternal">204</a>.  </span>This rhime is substituted in lieu of Sancho’s playing on the word <span lang="es"><i>fuera</i></span>, in the
original.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f205">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r205" class="pginternal">205</a>.  </span>Literally, ‘Use the times as I find them.’</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f206">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r206" class="pginternal">206</a>.  </span>This was Michael Scot, who lived in the thirteenth century, and was such an adept
in medicine, mathematicks, chymistry, alchymy, and other branches of natural knowledge,
that the vulgar looked upon him as a wizard or magician. But as this philosopher
died in 1291, and this conversation between Don Antonio and our knight must have happened
after the year 1605, when the first part of Don Quixote was licensed, how could the
disciple of Scot be in the house of Don Antonio? Yet this anachronism might easily pass
upon Don Quixote, as it related to matters of inchantment.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f207">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r207" class="pginternal">207</a>.  </span>But in this very chapter he has already told Don Quixote, that he knew the virtue of
the head from experience.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f208">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r208" class="pginternal">208</a>.  </span>Antonio’s wife must have been here before the others entered: for she is not in the
list of those who went in with her husband.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f209">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r209" class="pginternal">209</a>.  </span>Trifles.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f210">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r210" class="pginternal">210</a>.  </span>About Martinmas they killed the hogs designed for bacon.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f211">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r211" class="pginternal">211</a>.  </span>‘Wherever it may hit:’ an answer that has no affinity with the question, but the
faint resemblance of sound.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f212">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r212" class="pginternal">212</a>.  </span>In the original, ‘as fine as Mingo,’ who was a bad poet, and tawdry beau, contemporary
with Cervantes.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f213">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r213" class="pginternal">213</a>.  </span>Lines probably taken from some old ballad or romance.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote" id="f214">
<p class="c005"><span class="label"><a href="#r214" class="pginternal">214</a>.  </span>The author of the Second Part hinted, in his preface, a design of bringing his hero
into the field again, in Old Castile.</p>
</div>
